0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• usual dose: 3 doses series, 0.5 mL IM at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months
  • Adenocarcinoma in situ of cervix; Prophylaxis: (women through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Anal cancer, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis: (women, through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Anal cancer, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis: (men, through 21 years, and 22 through 26 years with immunocompromising conditions, HIV infection, and men who have sex with men) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or (through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Anal intraepithelial neoplasia, Grades 1, 2, and 3; Prophylaxis: (women, through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Anal intraepithelial neoplasia, Grades 1, 2, and 3; Prophylaxis: (men, through 21 years, and 22 through 26 years with immunocompromising conditions, HIV infection, and men who have sex with men) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months or (through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Cervical cancer, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis: (women through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 1, 2, 3; Prophylaxis: (women through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Genital warts, Virus types 6 and 11; Prophylaxis: (women, through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Genital warts, Virus types 6 and 11; Prophylaxis: (men, through 21 years, and 22 through 26 years with immunocompromising conditions, HIV infection, and men who have sex with men) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or (through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Malignant tumor of vagina, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis: (women through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Malignant tumor of vulva, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis: (women through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 2 and 3; Prophylaxis: (women through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), Grade 2 and 3; Prophylaxis: (women through 26 years) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• usual dose: 3 doses series, 0.5 mL IM at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months; minimum age for vaccination is 9 years
  • Adenocarcinoma in situ of cervix; Prophylaxis: (girls 9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Anal cancer, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis: (9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Anal intraepithelial neoplasia, Grades 1, 2, and 3; Prophylaxis: (9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Cervical cancer, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis: (girls 9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 1, 2, 3; Prophylaxis: (girls 9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Genital warts, Virus types 6 and 11; Prophylaxis: (9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Malignant tumor of vagina, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis: (girls 9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Malignant tumor of vulva, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis: (girls 9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 2 and 3; Prophylaxis: (girls 9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months
  • Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), Grade 2 and 3; Prophylaxis: (girls 9 years or older) 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at 0, 1 to 2, and 6 months, or at 0, 2, and 6 months

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Adenocarcinoma in situ of cervix; Prophylaxis
  • Anal cancer, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis
  • Anal intraepithelial neoplasia, Grades 1, 2, and 3; Prophylaxis
  • Cervical cancer, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis
  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 1, 2, 3; Prophylaxis
  • Genital warts, Virus types 6 and 11; Prophylaxis
  • Malignant tumor of vagina, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis
  • Malignant tumor of vulva, Virus types 16 and 18; Prophylaxis
  • Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 2 and 3; Prophylaxis
  • Vulval intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), Grade 2 and 3; Prophylaxis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Adenocarcinoma in situ of cervix, Due to nonvaccine HPV types; Prophylaxis
  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, Grade 1, 2, and 3 due to nonvaccine human papillomavirus types; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: hypersensitivity, including severe allergic reactions to yeast or following previous administration of human papillomavirus recombinant quadrivalent vaccine

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction
  • pregnancy; not recommended; if pregnancy occurs after starting vaccination series, delay remainder of series until pregnancy completed
  • syncope, sometimes associated with tonic-clonic movements and other seizure-like activity, has been reported; monitoring recommended
  • report suspected adverse events to Merck at 1-877-888-4231, or to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967 or www.vaers.hhs.gov

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (16.7% to 24.7%), Injection site pain (61.5% to 83.9%), Injection site pruritus (3.2%), Swelling at injection site (13.9% to 25.4%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (2% to 6.7%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (1.2% to 4%), Headache (12.3% to 28.2%)
  • Other:Fever (8.2% to 13%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Syncope, Venous thromboembolism
  • Gastrointestinal:Appendicitis (0.03%), Pancreatitis
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Disseminated encephalomyelitis, acute, Guillain-Barr syndrome, Motor neuron disease, Transverse myelopathy syndrome
  • Respiratory:Asthma, Bronchospasm

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: development of humoral immune response against human papillomavirus types 6, 11, 16, and 18

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intramuscular
  • administer in the deltoid region of the upper arm or in the higher anterolateral area of the thigh
  • do not inject intravascularly; subQ and intradermal administration have not been studied and therefore cannot be recommended
  • shake well before use; no dilution or reconstitution is necessary
  • may be administered concomitantly at the same visit, but at a different administration site, with the meningococcal vaccine (Menactra(R)); hepatitis B vaccine, recombinant (Recombivax HB(R)); or the reduced diphtheria toxoid, tetanus toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine, adsorbed (Adacel(R))

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• development of human papillomavirus (HPV) antibodies
  • absence of clinical manifestations of human papillomavirus infection (ie, cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, cervical cancer, cytological abnormalities)
  • signs of syncope, including tonic-clonic movements and other seizure-like activity, for 15 min after administration

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient that vaccine does not treat cancer (cervical, vulvar, vaginal, anal) or warts (anal, genital), and will not protect against other diseases caused by human papillomavirus.
  • Counsel female patient that cervical cancer screening is recommended after completed vaccine series.
  • Instruct patient to continue anal cancer screening if advised by physician.
  • Drug may cause nausea, dizziness, fever, pruritus, erythema, or swelling at injection site.
  • Inform patient that vaccine is given as 3 doses (0, 2, and 6 months) for complete vaccine series.
